threats.name: Spoofing
threats.description: Spoofing is an attack where an adversary pretends to be a trusted entity to gain unauthorized access or privileges. In automotive systems, this can involve impersonating ECUs, users, or external services to inject false data, gain access to restricted functions, or bypass authentication. Spoofing can compromise confidentiality and authenticity, leading to unauthorized actions or data leaks. Effective countermeasures include strong authentication, cryptographic protections, and monitoring for abnormal communication patterns.

threats.name: Man-in-the-Middle Attack
threats.description: A Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attack occurs when an attacker intercepts and potentially alters communications between two parties without their knowledge. In automotive systems, MitM can compromise data integrity, confidentiality, and authenticity. Using strong encryption and mutual authentication helps prevent MitM attacks.

threats.name: Identity Spoofing When Logging In With A Password
threats.description: This threat involves an attacker impersonating a legitimate user or component by guessing, stealing, or otherwise obtaining valid login credentials. In automotive environments, this could allow unauthorized access to vehicle systems, sensitive data, or remote services. Attackers may exploit weak passwords, credential reuse, or insecure storage to perform identity spoofing. Strong password policies, multi-factor authentication, and secure credential management help mitigate this risk.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Require Knowledge about the security behaviour of the product or system type.

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Requires knowledge about the asset to perform the attack that might be restricted to the product owner

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Always available without any time limitation

equipment.rationale: Equipment is readily available. May need only a laptop

threats.name: Software Packages Originating From An Unauthorized Source
threats.description: Attackers may attempt to install or distribute software packages that do not originate from trusted or authorized sources. In automotive systems, this can lead to the execution of malicious code, unauthorized modifications, or the introduction of vulnerabilities. Ensuring software authenticity through digital signatures, secure update mechanisms, and strict supply chain controls is essential to prevent this threat.

threats.name: Hardware Components Originating From An Unauthorized Source
threats.description: This threat involves the use of counterfeit, tampered, or unauthorized hardware components within the vehicle. Such components may introduce vulnerabilities, backdoors, or fail to meet safety and security standards. Attackers may exploit supply chain weaknesses to insert malicious hardware. Rigorous supplier vetting, component authentication, and supply chain monitoring are key defenses.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Requires an individual who is an experienced engineer and can understand architecture hardware components and complex systems

threats.name: Spoofing Of External Communication
threats.description: An attacker forges or manipulates information originating from external sources, such as cloud services, mobile apps, or external devices, to deceive the vehicle or its systems. This can result in unauthorized actions, data manipulation, or security bypasses. Validating the authenticity and integrity of all externally sourced data is critical to mitigate this threat.

threats.name: Spoofing Of Internal Communication
threats.description: This threat involves an attacker within the vehicle network generating or modifying messages to impersonate legitimate ECUs or sensors. By injecting false data or commands, attackers can disrupt vehicle functions, mislead safety systems, or bypass security controls. Message authentication and network segmentation help defend against internal spoofing.

threats.name: Location Spoofing
threats.description: Location spoofing occurs when an attacker manipulates or falsifies the vehicle's reported location, typically by interfering with GPS or other positioning systems. This can mislead navigation, enable theft, or bypass location-based restrictions. Defenses include multi-source location verification, anomaly detection, and secure GPS modules.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Need to be experienced with the security behavioral of the system

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: It will require confidential information about the item that may be available within the developer teams and shared with other teams

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: May need access to the system hardware or software component

equipment.rationale: Tools are easily available online such as a VPN connection

threats.name: Exploitation Of Spoofing Weaknesses
threats.description: Attackers exploit known or unknown weaknesses in authentication or identity verification mechanisms to successfully perform spoofing attacks. This can lead to unauthorized access, data manipulation, or control over vehicle functions. Regular security assessments, patching, and robust authentication protocols are necessary to reduce this risk.

threats.name: Tampering
threats.description: Tampering refers to the unauthorized modification of data, code, or hardware within the vehicle system. Attackers may alter firmware, configuration files, or physical components to disrupt operations, introduce vulnerabilities, or bypass security controls. Integrity checks, secure boot, and physical protections are key countermeasures.

threats.name: Manipulation Of Transferred Data In External Communication
threats.description: This threat involves an attacker altering data as it is transferred from external sources to the vehicle, such as over wireless or wired channels. Manipulation can lead to incorrect system behavior, unauthorized actions, or the introduction of malicious code. In automotive systems, this could affect firmware updates, telematics, or infotainment data. Ensuring data integrity and authenticity during transfer is essential to mitigate this risk.

threats.name: Manipulation Of Transferred Data In Internal Communication
threats.description: Attackers may intercept and modify data as it moves between internal vehicle components, such as ECUs or sensors. This can disrupt normal operations, cause safety issues, or enable further attacks. Automotive systems must use message authentication and integrity checks to detect and prevent unauthorized internal data manipulation.

threats.name: Manipulation Of Data During Computation
threats.description: Manipulation during computation refers to altering data or processes while they are being processed by the vehicle's systems. Attackers may exploit software vulnerabilities or inject malicious code to change outcomes, bypass controls, or cause malfunctions. Protecting computation integrity is vital for reliable and safe vehicle operation.

threats.name: Manipulation Of Data Residing In Memory
threats.description: This threat targets the unauthorized modification of memory contents within automotive systems. Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities to alter variables, firmware, or configuration data stored in memory, potentially leading to system instability or security breaches. Memory protection mechanisms and regular integrity checks help mitigate this risk.

threats.name: Manipulation Of Code
threats.description: Manipulation of code involves unauthorized changes to software or firmware running on vehicle systems. Attackers may inject, modify, or replace code to introduce vulnerabilities, gain control, or disrupt operations. Secure boot, code signing, and regular software validation are essential defenses against this threat.

threats.name: Parameter Injection
threats.description: Parameter injection occurs when an attacker supplies malicious input to vehicle systems, causing them to behave unexpectedly or execute unauthorized commands. This can exploit weaknesses in input validation, leading to security bypasses or system compromise. Strong input validation and sanitization are key countermeasures.

threats.name: Code Injection
threats.description: Code injection is a technique where attackers introduce malicious code into a vehicle's software environment, often exploiting vulnerabilities in input handling or communication protocols. This can result in unauthorized actions, data theft, or system compromise. Preventing code injection requires secure coding practices and input validation.

threats.name: Command Injection
threats.description: Command injection involves an attacker inserting unauthorized commands into a system interface, causing the vehicle to execute unintended actions. This can lead to privilege escalation, data manipulation, or system disruption. Proper input validation and command parsing are essential to prevent this threat.

threats.name: Fault Injection
threats.description: Fault injection is a technique where attackers deliberately introduce faults or errors into hardware or software to disrupt normal operation, bypass security controls, or reveal vulnerabilities. In automotive systems, this can include voltage glitches, clock manipulation, or electromagnetic interference to alter system behavior or extract sensitive data. Countermeasures include fault detection, redundancy, and robust error handling.

threats.name: Replay Attack
threats.description: A replay attack occurs when an attacker captures valid data transmissions and retransmits them to trick the system into performing unauthorized actions. In automotive systems, this can affect authentication, remote control, or data integrity. Using nonces, timestamps, and message authentication codes helps defend against replay attacks.

threats.name: Manipulation Of Configuration And Settings
threats.description: Attackers may attempt to alter configuration files or system settings to weaken security, enable unauthorized features, or disrupt normal operation. In automotive systems, this can impact safety, privacy, or system reliability. Protecting configuration data with access controls and integrity checks is critical.

threats.name: Protocol Manipulation
threats.description: Protocol manipulation in automotive systems involves unauthorized changes or exploitation of in-vehicle communication protocols such as CAN, LIN, or automotive Ethernet. Attackers may alter protocol messages, exploit weaknesses in protocol design, or force ECUs to operate outside intended parameters. This can result in data corruption, unauthorized control of vehicle functions, or system malfunctions. Defenses include strict protocol validation, secure protocol design, and monitoring for abnormal protocol activity on vehicle networks.

threats.name: Exploitation Of Tampering Weaknesses
threats.description: Attackers exploit known or unknown weaknesses in software, hardware, or physical protections to successfully perform tampering attacks. This can result in unauthorized modification of data, code, or components, potentially leading to system instability, safety risks, or bypassing security controls. Regular security assessments, patching, physical protections, and robust integrity verification mechanisms are necessary to reduce this risk.

threats.name: Physical Data Tampering
threats.description: Physical data tampering involves attackers gaining physical access to a vehicle or its components to directly modify or corrupt data stored on storage devices, memory chips, or communication interfaces. This can result in the alteration of critical information, injection of malicious code, or disruption of normal system operation. Countermeasures include tamper-evident seals, encrypted storage, and disabling unnecessary physical interfaces.

threats.name: BGA Data Tampering
threats.description: This threat involves tampering with data on integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to BGA (Ball Grid Array) packages. Attackers may use advanced chip-off, microprobing, or decapsulation methods to modify internal memory or firmware, potentially injecting malicious code or corrupting data. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: LGA Data Tampering
threats.description: This threat involves tampering with data on integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to LGA (Land Grid Array) packages. Attackers may use chip-off, microprobing, or decapsulation to modify internal memory or firmware, potentially altering system behavior or injecting malicious code. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: QFP Data Tampering
threats.description: This threat involves tampering with data on integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to QFP (Quad Flat Package) chips. Attackers may decapsulate the chip and probe internal connections or memory to modify firmware or critical data, potentially disrupting system operation. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: TSOP Data Tampering
threats.description: This threat involves tampering with data on integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to TSOP (Thin Small Outline Package) chips. Attackers may target exposed pins or decapsulate the chip to modify internal memory, risking corruption of firmware or critical data. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: WSON Data Tampering
threats.description: This threat involves tampering with data on integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to WSON (Very-very-thin Small Outline No-lead) packages. Attackers may use advanced techniques to modify internal memory or firmware, risking corruption of sensitive data or injection of malicious code. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: Repudiation
threats.description: Repudiation occurs when an entity denies having performed an action, such as sending a message or making a change, making it difficult to prove responsibility. In automotive systems, this can hinder forensic investigations or accountability for unauthorized actions. Implementing strong logging, digital signatures, and audit trails helps prevent repudiation and ensures actions can be traced to their source.

threats.name: Non-Repudiation Software Mechanism Bypass
threats.description: This threat involves bypassing software mechanisms designed to ensure non-repudiation, such as digital signatures or audit logs. Attackers may alter or disable these controls to hide their actions. Ensuring robust, tamper-evident non-repudiation mechanisms is critical for accountability.

threats.name: Exploitation Of Repudiation Weaknesses
threats.description: This threat involves attackers exploiting insufficient logging or weak authentication to deny their actions or make it difficult to trace malicious activities. In automotive environments, this can prevent detection of unauthorized changes or misuse. Robust audit mechanisms and tamper-evident logs are essential to counter repudiation exploitation.

threats.name: Information Disclosure
threats.description: Information disclosure refers to the unauthorized exposure of sensitive data, such as personal information, cryptographic keys, or system details. In automotive systems, this can occur through insecure communications, weak access controls, or software vulnerabilities. Protecting data confidentiality is critical to prevent privacy breaches and further attacks.

threats.name: Interception
threats.description: Interception is the unauthorized capture of data as it is transmitted between components or systems. Attackers may eavesdrop on network traffic to obtain sensitive information, such as credentials or commands. In automotive networks, encryption and secure communication protocols are vital to prevent interception.

threats.name: Interception Of Internal Data
threats.description: This threat involves capturing data exchanged within the vehicle, such as between ECUs or sensors. Attackers may exploit unencrypted internal communications to access sensitive information or manipulate system behavior. Implementing internal network segmentation and encryption helps mitigate this risk.

threats.name: Interception Of External Data
threats.description: Attackers may intercept data transmitted between the vehicle and external entities, such as backend servers or mobile devices. This can lead to the exposure of personal data, credentials, or operational commands. Secure external communications using encryption and authentication are essential defenses.

threats.name: Unintended Disclosure Of PII Data
threats.description: Unintended disclosure of personally identifiable information (PII) occurs when sensitive user data is exposed due to misconfiguration, software flaws, insecure interfaces or undesired logging. In automotive systems, this can compromise user privacy and regulatory compliance. Strong data protection and privacy controls are necessary to prevent such leaks.

threats.name: Software Or Firmware Disclosure
threats.description: This threat involves unauthorized access to or exposure of proprietary software or firmware. Attackers may reverse engineer or extract code to find vulnerabilities or intellectual property. Protecting firmware with encryption and access controls helps prevent disclosure and subsequent exploitation.

threats.name: Functional Observation
threats.description: Functional observation refers to monitoring or analyzing the behavior of vehicle systems to gather information about their operation. Attackers may use this data to identify vulnerabilities or plan further attacks. Limiting debug interfaces and monitoring for unauthorized access can reduce this risk.

threats.name: Side Channel Attacks
threats.description: Side channel attacks exploit indirect information leaked by a system's physical implementation, such as timing, power consumption, electromagnetic emissions, or acoustic signals, to extract sensitive data or cryptographic keys. In automotive systems, attackers may use side channels to bypass security controls or gain unauthorized access to confidential information. Countermeasures include shielding, noise generation, and designing hardware and software to minimize information leakage.

threats.name: Reverse Engineering
threats.description: Reverse engineering is the process of analyzing hardware or software to understand its design, functionality, or vulnerabilities. In automotive systems, attackers may reverse engineer ECUs, firmware, or communication protocols to find weaknesses. Obfuscation, encryption, and anti-tamper measures help deter reverse engineering.

threats.name: Physical Data Extraction
threats.description: Physical data extraction involves attackers gaining physical access to a vehicle or its components to directly extract data from storage devices, memory chips, or communication interfaces. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information, intellectual property, or cryptographic keys. Countermeasures include tamper-evident seals, encrypted storage, and disabling unnecessary physical interfaces.

threats.name: BGA Data Extraction
threats.description: This threat involves extracting data from integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to BGA (Ball Grid Array) packages. BGA chips have solder balls on the underside, making direct probing difficult, but attackers may use advanced chip-off, microprobing, or decapsulation methods to access internal memory or firmware. These techniques can expose sensitive data or intellectual property stored within the chip. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: LGA Data Extraction
threats.description: This threat involves extracting data from integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to LGA (Land Grid Array) packages. LGA chips have flat contact pads on the underside, which can be accessed by attackers using chip-off, microprobing, or decapsulation to reach internal memory or firmware. The flat pad design may allow for easier rework or probing compared to BGA, but still requires specialized equipment. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: QFP Data Extraction
threats.description: This threat involves extracting data from integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to QFP (Quad Flat Package) chips. QFP chips have leads extending from all four sides, making them more accessible for chip-off or microprobing attacks. Attackers may decapsulate the chip and probe internal connections or memory to extract firmware or sensitive data. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: TSOP Data Extraction
threats.description: This threat involves extracting data from integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to TSOP (Thin Small Outline Package) chips. TSOP chips have thin, flat leads on two sides, making them relatively accessible for chip-off, microprobing, or decapsulation. Attackers may target exposed pins or decapsulate the chip to access internal memory, risking exposure of sensitive data or firmware. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: WSON Data Extraction
threats.description: This threat involves extracting data from integrated circuits using physical access techniques specific to WSON (Very-very-thin Small Outline No-lead) packages. WSON chips have no leads and a flat, exposed pad on the underside, making them challenging to probe but still vulnerable to chip-off, microprobing, or decapsulation. Attackers may use advanced techniques to access internal memory or firmware, risking exposure of sensitive data. Countermeasures include epoxy encapsulation, encrypted storage, and disabling debug/test interfaces.

threats.name: Denial Of Service
threats.description: Denial of Service (DoS) attacks aim to disrupt the normal operation of vehicle systems by overwhelming resources, blocking communications, or causing system crashes. In automotive environments, DoS can affect safety-critical functions. Rate limiting, redundancy, and robust error handling are key defenses.

threats.name: Disrupt Wireless Data Transmission
threats.description: This threat involves interfering with or blocking wireless communications, such as Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, or cellular signals. Attackers may use jamming or flooding techniques to prevent data exchange, impacting vehicle connectivity and safety. Using robust wireless protocols and interference detection can help mitigate this risk.

threats.name: Disrupt Wired Data Transmission
threats.description: Attackers may disrupt wired communications within the vehicle, such as CAN, LIN, or Ethernet networks, by injecting noise, disconnecting cables, or sending malformed messages. This can lead to loss of functionality or safety risks. Physical protections and message validation are important countermeasures.

threats.name: Disrupt Computation
threats.description: Disrupting computation involves interfering with the processing capabilities of ECUs or other vehicle systems, potentially causing malfunctions or degraded performance. Attackers may exploit software bugs or resource exhaustion. Monitoring system health and implementing fail-safes can reduce the impact.

threats.name: Flooding
threats.description: Flooding attacks overwhelm vehicle networks or systems with excessive traffic or requests, leading to degraded performance or denial of service. In automotive environments, this can disrupt critical communications or functions. Rate limiting and anomaly detection are effective defenses.

threats.name: Jamming
threats.description: Jamming is the deliberate interference with wireless signals to block or degrade communications. In automotive systems, jamming can affect GPS, Wi-Fi, or cellular connectivity, impacting navigation and remote services. Detection mechanisms and frequency hopping can help counter jamming.

threats.name: GPS Jamming
threats.description: GPS jamming targets the vehicle's positioning system by emitting signals that interfere with GPS reception. This can cause navigation errors, disable location-based services, or enable theft. Using multi-source positioning and jamming detection can help maintain reliable navigation.

threats.name: Excessive Allocation Of Resources
threats.description: This threat involves intentionally consuming excessive system resources, such as memory, CPU, or bandwidth, to degrade performance or cause failures. In automotive systems, resource exhaustion can impact safety and reliability. Resource management and monitoring are essential to prevent abuse.

threats.name: Resource Leak Exposure And Depletion
threats.description: Resource leaks occur when system resources are not properly released, leading to gradual depletion and potential system failure. Attackers may exploit software bugs to trigger leaks and cause denial of service. Regular code reviews and resource monitoring help mitigate this threat.

threats.name: Denial Of Wallet
threats.description: Denial of Wallet (DoW) is a cyberattack that targets an organization's financial resources by generating excessive costs for their cloud computing or serverless platforms. Attackers overload the system with requests, causing increased resource consumption and high operational expenses, as the cloud instances are autoscaling up in order to respond. Countermeasures include usage monitoring, proper autoscaling configurations defining minimum and maximum instances, spending limits, and strong authentication for resource-intensive operations.

threats.name: Elevation Of Privilege
threats.description: Elevation of privilege occurs when an attacker gains higher access rights than intended, allowing them to perform unauthorized actions. In automotive systems, this can lead to control over critical functions or data. Implementing strict access controls and privilege separation is crucial.

threats.name: Gaining Access Via Privilege Escalation
threats.description: Access via privilege escalation refers to exploiting vulnerabilities or misconfigurations to gain unauthorized access to restricted areas or functions. In automotive environments, this can compromise system integrity and safety. Regular security assessments and least-privilege principles help prevent escalation.

threats.name: Gaining Processing Capabilities Via Privilege Escalation
threats.description: This threat involves gaining unauthorized processing capabilities, such as executing privileged code or accessing protected memory. Attackers may exploit software flaws or weak isolation. Strong process isolation and secure coding practices are key defenses.

threats.name: Privilege Abuse
threats.description: Privilege abuse occurs when authorized users or components misuse their access rights to perform malicious or unintended actions. In automotive systems, this can result in data leaks, system changes, or safety risks. Monitoring and auditing privileged actions help detect and prevent abuse.

threats.name: Open Development Or Debug Channels
threats.description: Leaving development or debug channels open in production systems can expose sensitive interfaces to attackers. In automotive environments, this may allow unauthorized access, data extraction, or system manipulation. Disabling or securing development channels before deployment is essential.

threats.name: Exploitation Of Software Weakness
threats.description: Attackers exploit vulnerabilities or flaws in software, such as bugs, insecure coding practices, or outdated libraries, to compromise automotive systems. This can lead to elevation of privilege and in sequence unauthorized access, data manipulation, or system disruption. Regular software updates, secure coding, and vulnerability management are essential countermeasures.

threats.name: Exploitation Of Misconfiguration
threats.description: Attackers take advantage of insecure or incorrect system configurations, such as default passwords, open ports, or excessive privileges, to gain unauthorized access or control. Proper configuration management, regular audits, and adherence to security best practices help mitigate this threat.

threats.name: Reconnaisance
threats.description: The adversary is trying to gather information they can use to plan future operations. Reconnaissance consists of techniques that involve adversaries actively or passively gathering information that can be used to support an attack on the vehicle. These techniques focus on sources the adversary can target to obtain information, rather than specific information found. These information can be leveraged by the adversary to aid in other phases of the adversary lifecycle, such as using gathered information to plan and execute Initial Access, to scope and prioritize post-compromise objectives, or to drive and lead further Reconnaissance efforts. This tactic was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: Gather Target Information - from Other
threats.description: The adversary gathers information by directly targeting sources that do not involve the vehicle and its services. Targeting organizations are included, such OEMs, suppliers, service providers, and dealerships. This may involve physically breaching an organization's premises, infiltrating networks, or exploiting personnel with privileged access. Other accessible sources include anything in the surface web and dark web. Specific information might include manuals, breach reports, engineering data (e.g., architecture, design, and schematics), and technical data sheets related to vehicles.

threats.name: Gather Target Information - from Vehicle
threats.description: The adversary gathers information by targeting a vehicle's hardware and/or communication environment. Hardware includes physical components, such as Electronic Control Units (ECUs), sensors, FPGAs, microcontrollers, or SoCs. The communication environment involves any physical communication and wireless communication involving the vehicle. Examples include CAN, LIN, Bluetooth, RF, Cellular, etc. Communications with external infrastructure are included, such as Over-The-Air (OTA), cloud services, back-end infrastructure, charging stations, fleet management systems, and telematics platforms. Specific information might include hardware details such as firmware details, communication interfaces, and hardware vulnerabilities. communication details such as network details, protocols used, internal vehicle services, communication to external services interacting with the vehicle, and vulnerabilities within services.

threats.name: Manipulate Environment
threats.description: The adversary is attempting to intercept or manipulate network traffic to or from a vehicle, or manipulate the vehicle's natural environment to achieve their goal without physically manipulating the vehicle itself. This category refers to network-based techniques that an adversary may utilize to achieve their objectives or create conditions conducive to employing techniques from the 'initial access' tactic. These techniques involve intercepting or manipulating network traffic to and from the vehicle's mobile device.Additionally, this category covers techniques that involve manipulating the physical environment surrounding a vehicle to confuse its sensors or artificial intelligence processing systems, without directly altering the vehicle's mechanics or components.This tactic was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: Adversarial Machine Learning
threats.description: As per Wikipedia, adversarial machine learning can be defined as a machine learning technique that attempts to fool models by supplying deceptive input. In the context of automotive cybersecurity, the adversary could try to use adversarial machine learning techniques to cause vehicle perception systems to misclassify objects, fail to detect obstacles, misinterpret road signs, respond inappropriately to road conditions, and others.For example, it may be possible to create an image that appears as a stop sign to a human but is interpreted by a vehicle's vision system as a speed limit sign. It has been shown that some adversarial machine learning techniques could be used to attack multi-sensor fusion systems and possibly affect the behavior of driver assist or autonomous driving features.

specialistExpertise.rationale: A deep understanding of machine learning modules from a theoretical and practical perspective is required to even begin planning such an attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: A good understanding of the internal model, what protections are in place, and the models used to train the current model are required in order to successfully break the machine learning system

threats.name: Analog Sensor Attacks
threats.description: The adversary may use analog sensor attacks to disrupt the availability of vehicle's analog sensors, and possibly control their output. Examples of these techniques include shining a laser into a Lidar receiver, transmitting an interfering radar signal that causes a vehicle to perceive a vehicle or obstacle where there isn't one, or transmitting inaudible voice commands to a vehicle's voice assistant.One survey paper found that a vehicle's Lidar, camera, radar, ultrasonic, and magnetic sensors could be jammed, and in some cases their outputs controlled, using analog sensor attack techniques.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of general vehicle components and systems is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: As long as general car systems are understood and there are no unique controls in place; public knowledge or some simple tinkering under the hood  would provide the information required for this type of attack

threats.name: Downgrade to Insecure Protocols
threats.description: An adversary could cause the vehicle's wireless interfaces to use less secure protocols, for example by jamming frequencies used by newer protocols such as LTE and only allowing older protocols such as GSM to communicate. Use of less secure protocols may make communication easier to eavesdrop upon or manipulate. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Discovering a way to downgrade to insecure protocols can take time; more so if updates are continuously pushed

specialistExpertise.rationale: Depending on the system, specific equipment is going to be a necessity

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of the previous protocols and current ones are required in order to make a downgrade possible

threats.name: Jamming or Denial of Service
threats.description: An attacker could jam radio signals (e.g. Wi-Fi, cellular, GPS, key fobs) to prevent the mobile device from communicating. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: This particular ratings it the most contentious. Depending on the system that the attacker wants to jam it could very easily be public knowledge such as standard WIFI protocols; or it could be a system that is proprietary and requires much more knowledge about the specific item to accomplish

threats.name: Manipulate Communication
threats.description: If network traffic between the vehicle and a remote server or mobile device is not securely protected, then an attacker positioned on the network may be able to manipulate network communication without being detected. For example, FireEye researchers found in 2014 that 68% of the top 1,000 free applications in the Google Play Store had at least one Transport Layer Security (TLS) implementation vulnerability potentially opening the applications' network traffic to man-in-the-middle attacks. V2X spoofing, GPS spoofing, etc., can also be considered as another form of manipulate communication. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Once again depends on the encryption methodology used to protect the information

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker will need to know what type of controls are put into place in order to have a chance at breaking the encryption

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Depends on the type of encryption used to protect as some are mathematically superior to others

threats.name: Relay Communications
threats.description: The adversary may be able to relay communications to make a device that the vehicle trusts appear closer to the vehicle than it really is. An example of this technique is the use of a key fob relay attack, which a car thief could use to unlock, start, and drive away with a vehicle.

elapsedTime.rationale: The attackers will need to first discover the methodology for the wireless communication and any controls put into place before they can begin to attempt attacks

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of wireless transmission protocols is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of internal controls is needed in order for the attack to be successful

threats.name: Rogue Cellular Base Station
threats.description: An adversary could set up a rogue cellular base station and then use it to eavesdrop on or manipulate the vehicle cellular interface's communication. A compromised cellular femtocell could be used to carry out this technique.This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of the vehicle system, how to create a system, and then how to have the vehicle recognize the fraudulent system as legitimate is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of the internal systems and controls are required in order to exploit them

equipment.rationale: Specialized equipment is required for the attacker to pass off a non-legitimate device as acceptable to the system

threats.name: Rogue Wi-Fi Access Point
threats.description: An adversary could set up unauthorized Wi-Fi access points or compromise existing access points and, if the device connects to them, carry out network-based attacks such as eavesdropping on or modifying network communication Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK for Mobile.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of the WIFI system used by the product, the protocols involved, and how to mask a WIFI network is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of the internal WIFI protocols of the product is required for this attack to work

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The WIFI of automotive products is used quite frequently, so the attacker has the opportunity to place their network as legitimate so long as the car is in use/service

threats.name: Initial Access
threats.description: Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK: The adversary is trying to get into the vehicle network. The initial access tactic represents the vectors adversaries use to gain an initial foothold onto a vehicle.

threats.name: Aftermarket, Customer, or Dealer Equipment
threats.description: Adversaries may take use aftermarket, customer, or dealer equipment as an initial access point into the vehicle. Paired devices, such as a customer's smart phone, often possess valid credentials for the vehicle's Bluetooth and Wi-Fi networks, access to phone projection technologies, and may be connected to USB ports. Dealer test and diagnostic tools are typically connected to a vehicle's OBD-II port, which may provide direct access to a vehicle network; these tools may also have access to credentials for running diagnostic procedures. Third-party OBD-II accessories, such as insurance dongles and fleet management dongles, may introduce a wireless ingress points to the vehicle through its OBD-II port. These devices may also be used as a post-exploitation command-and-control mechanism, and to exfiltrate data from a vehicle.

threats.name: Browser Compromise
threats.description: A browser compromise is when an adversary gains access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing. With this technique, the user's web browser is targeted for exploitation. For example, a website may contain malicious media content intended to exploit vulnerabilities in media parsers as demonstrated by the Android Stagefright vulnerability. Based on MITRE ATT&CK's Drive-by Compromise' technique.

elapsedTime.rationale: Existing browser exploits would function; but they would need some modifications to access certain parts of the vehicle architecture

specialistExpertise.rationale: Basic knowledge of browser exploits and information exchange protocols is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker would need some knowledge of the information protocols within the vehicle to access the information they target; but otherwise everything is fairly public domain or otherwise easily accessible

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Possible anytime the vehicle browser is in use; which could vary from user to user

equipment.rationale: A simple computer is the only requirement

threats.name: Exploit Via Radio Interface
threats.description: The vehicle may be targeted for exploitation through its interface to cellular networks or other radio interfaces. Baseband Vulnerability Exploitation: A message sent over a radio interface such as cellular, Bluetooth, GPS, NFC, Wi-Fi, TPMS, DAB, or others to the vehicle could exploit a vulnerability. Malicious SMS Message: An SMS message could contain content designed to exploit vulnerabilities in the SMS parser on the receiving device. An SMS message could also contain a link to a web site containing malicious content designed to exploit the device web browser. Vulnerable SIM cards may be remotely exploited and reprogrammed via SMS messages. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Some research time for known exploits and certain aspects of the vehicle architecture is required

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of basic radio interfaces and potential controls is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Most of the knowledge for these interfaces are public facing, however certain aspects that an attacker may want to access may be proprietary or otherwise hidden

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Unlimited as the surfaces are essentially always in use by the end-user

equipment.rationale: Depending on the desired affect, either specialized or standard equipment would be required

threats.name: Exploit Via Removable Media
threats.description: Adversaries may gain initial access to an automotive environment by copying malware to removable media and taking advantage of Autorun features or automatic parsing of file (e.g., MP3s) when the device is inserted into a system and executes. This may occur through manual manipulation of the media, modification of systems used to initially format the media, or modification to the media's firmware itself. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Creating the removable media exploit is quite quick, having it function as intended within the vehicle requires more research

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of removable media device exploits is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker would need to understand if there are any controls in place to prevent this type of attack for it to work

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Depending on the attackers relation to the vehicle owner, it may be quite difficult to gain access to the car and insert the removable media

equipment.rationale: A standard computer and removable media device are all that is needed and is quite readily available

threats.name: Malicious App
threats.description: Malicious applications could be used by adversaries to gain a presence on a vehicle. Some vehicles are configured to allow application installation only from an authorized app store, and an adversary may seek to place a malicious application in an authorized app store, enabling the application to be installed onto targeted devices. App stores typically require developer registration and use vetting techniques to identify malicious applications, which adversaries may seek to circumvent by downloading new code at runtime or by using obfuscation techniques. Adversaries may also seek to evade vetting by placing code in a malicious application to detect whether it is running in an app analysis environment and, if so, avoid performing malicious actions while under analysis. Adversaries may also use fake identities, payment cards, etc., to create developer accounts to publish malicious applications to app stores. Adversaries may also use control of a target's Google account to use the Google Play Store's remote installation capability to install apps onto the Android devices associated with the Google account. Only applications that are available for download through the Google Play Store can be remotely installed using this technique. This Malicious app' technique also includes installing a malicious application on targeted mobile devices without involving an authorized app store (e.g., Google Play Store or the OEM's app store). Adversaries may wish to avoid placing malicious applications in an authorized app store due to increased potential risk of detection or other reasons. However, mobile devices often are configured to allow application installation only from an authorized app store which would prevent this technique from working. Delivery methods for the malicious application include spearphishing attachments, spearphishing links, and third party app stores (as opposed to an authorized app store that the device implicitly trusts as part of its default behavior), which may not apply the same level of scrutiny to apps as applied by an authorized app store. Some Android malware comes with functionality to install additional applications, either automatically or when the adversary instructs it to. Finally, this technique also includes situations where an adversary develops and distributes malware that masquerades as as a legitimate application. This can be done in two different ways: by embedding the malware in a legitimate application, or by pretending to be a legitimate application. Embedding the malware in a legitimate application is done by downloading the application, disassembling it, adding the malicious code, and then re-assembling it.The app would appear to be the original app, but would contain additional malicious functionality. The adversary could then publish the malicious application to app stores or use another delivery method. Pretending to be a legitimate application relies heavily on lack of scrutinization by the user. Typically, a malicious app pretending to be a legitimate one will have many similar details as the legitimate one, such as name, icon, and description. Malicious applications may also masquerade as legitimate applications when requesting access to the accessibility service in order to appear as legitimate to the user, increasing the likelihood that the access will be granted. This technique is a combination of three techniques described in the MITRE ATT&CK matrix for mobile devices: Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store, Deliver Malicious App via Other Means, and Masquerade as Legitimate Application.

elapsedTime.rationale: Getting the application approved for the storefront is a major hurdle that will take a long time to overcome; it will then quickly be taken down after user reports as well

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of software engineering, automotive architecture, and validation spoofing for the storefront is required for this attack to function

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: In-depth knowledge of a variety of vehicle eco-systems is required for this attack to function

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Unlimited as the user only needs to download and execute the application

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required to create the application

threats.name: Phishing
threats.description: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns. Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: These types of attacks can happen within the span of an hour

specialistExpertise.rationale: Some knowledge is required in order to pass as a legitimate source; but nothing intensive

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: specific knowledge surrounding the vehicle is not required for this type of attack

threats.name: Physical Modification
threats.description: The adversary can make physical modifications to the vehicle's ECUs, wiring harnesses, and can replace ECUs. Some ECUs possess physical debug interfaces that are not exposed outside their enclosures. With sufficient time, an adversary can partially disassemble the vehicle to obtain physical access to these ECUs, remove their enclosures, and connect or solder cables to access these debug interfaces. Direct physical access can also be used by an adversary to attempt different types of glitching attacks, side channel attacks, memory removal, reprogramming, and replacement, as well as others. To gain access to a vehicle an adversary could replace an ECU with one they have modified ahead of time (e.g., a modified service or junkyard part).

elapsedTime.rationale: Malicious parts would need to be created and tested before this attack could be performed

specialistExpertise.rationale: Depending on the installation of the part; it could be quite simple or require a bit more experience to perform correctly

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge about internal protocols is required for this type of attack to function

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Physical access to the vehicle is required; and depending on the context that time window could be incredibly short

threats.name: Supply Chain Compromise
threats.description: Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. Supply chain compromise can take place at any stage of the supply chain including:  - Manipulation of development tools, - Manipulation of a development environment, - Manipulation of source code repositories (public or private), - Manipulation of source code in open-source dependencies, - Manipulation of software update/distribution mechanisms, - Compromised/infected system images (multiple cases of removable media infected at the factory), - Replacement of legitimate software with modified versions, - Sales of modified/counterfeit products to legitimate distributors, - Shipment interdiction. While supply chain compromise can impact any component of hardware or software, attackers looking to gain execution have often focused on malicious additions to legitimate software in software distribution or update channels.  Targeting may be specific to a desired victim set  or malicious software may be distributed to a broad set of consumers but only move on to additional tactics on specific victims.  Popular open source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may also be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: The attacker would need to contribute to the project and then ensure that it went to market

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: This should be a non-factor as the attacker would not need to gain access to this information; as the attack dictates they would already have it

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The attacker would need to know when certain parts are being designed and become a part of that design team

equipment.rationale: Equipment needs would be handled by the vendor; so the attacker does not need to make an investment here

threats.name: Execution
threats.description: The adversary is trying to run malicious code. Execution of the malicious code involves infiltrating an ECU's memory space, where it can manipulate data and instructions to carry out unauthorized operations. This process often involves exploiting vulnerabilities in the component's firmware or software. Techniques that run malicious code are often paired with techniques from all other tactics to achieve broader goals, like moving laterally in a vehicle network or affecting vehicle functions. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK for mobile.

threats.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
threats.description: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries. These interfaces and languages provide ways of interacting with computer systems and are a common feature across many different platforms. Most systems come with some built-in command-line interface and scripting capabilities. There are also cross-platform interpreters such as Python, as well as those commonly associated with client applications such as JavaScript and Visual Basic. Adversaries may abuse these technologies in various ways as a means of executing arbitrary commands. Commands and scripts can be embedded in Initial Access payloads delivered to victims as lure documents or as secondary payloads downloaded from an existing C2. Adversaries may also execute commands through interactive terminals/shells. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Research into the controls surrounding the command line interface must be done before this type of attack can succeed

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of basic scripting and knowledge of how to gain access to the command-line for a vehicle is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker must know some of the controls and coding vulnerabilities of the vehicle for the attack to work

equipment.rationale: A simple computer is required for this attack

threats.name: Native API
threats.description: Adversaries may directly interact with the native OS application programming interface (API) to execute behaviors. Native APIs provide a controlled means of calling low-level OS services within the kernel, such as those involving hardware/devices, memory, and processes. These native APIs are leveraged by the OS during system boot (when other system components are not yet initialized) as well as carrying out tasks and requests during routine operations. Functionality provided by native APIs are often also exposed to user-mode applications via interfaces and libraries. For example, functions such as the Windows API CreateProcess() or GNU fork() will allow programs and scripts to start other processes. This may allow API callers to execute a binary, run a CLI command, load modules, etc. as thousands of similar API functions exist for various system operations. Higher level software frameworks, such as Microsoft .NET and macOS Cocoa, are also available to interact with native APIs. These frameworks typically provide language wrappers/abstractions to API functionalities and are designed for ease-of-use/portability of code. Adversaries may abuse these native API functions as a means of executing behaviors. Similar to Command and Scripting Interpreter, the native API and its hierarchy of interfaces, provide mechanisms to interact with and utilize various components of a victimized system. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Spoofing the API authentication is required for this attack to work and that would take time to find vulnerabilities and implement them. This category is largely dependent on if secure coding practices were used during its creation

specialistExpertise.rationale: General programming knowledge and how to access confidential APIs is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker must have knowledge of the API itself, and how to access it and bypass the authentication and logs in order to be successful

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The native API is an attack surface that is always available

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required for this attack

threats.name: Abuse Standard Diagnostic Protocol to Temporarily Modify Execution
threats.description: Standard diagnostic protocols can be used to write directly to RAM such as the UDS service, WriteMemoryByAddress (in contrast to RequestDownload, which usually targets writing to persistent flash). This can be used to modify sensitive data (for example verification keys) or change execution through writing to stack memory, or direct execution (if the device offers execution from RAM).

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required for this attack

threats.name: Persistence
threats.description: The adversary is trying to maintain their foothold. Persistence consists of techniques that adversaries use to keep access to vehicle systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions that could cut off their access. Techniques used for persistence include any access, action, or configuration changes that let them maintain their foothold on vehicle systems, such as replacing or hijacking legitimate code or adding startup code. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: Abuse Standard Diagnostic Protocol for Persistence
threats.description: The adversary can attempt to use standard diagnostic protocols to persist their presence on an ECU. For example, UDS' capabilities for firmware updates and 'download-and-execute' can be abused by an adversary to achieve persistence.

specialistExpertise.rationale: While UDS is a standardized protocol, knowing how to use it as an exploit point requires greater expertise

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some elements of the vehicle that the attacker may want access to could be proprietary

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Access to the vehicles UDS access point is required

equipment.rationale: UDS reader/writers are quite easy and affordable

threats.name: Disable Software Update
threats.description: The adversary may disable or modify an ECU's software update mechanism so that it cannot be used to restore the device to an uncompromised state.

elapsedTime.rationale: Simly preventing the connection is all that is required for this attack to function

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of how to prevent the vehicle from communicating with its software update server is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Simply understanding how to prevent wireless communication is required for this attack

equipment.rationale: Some fairly minor specialized equipment would be required for this attack

threats.name: Modify OS Kernel, Boot Partition, or System Partition
threats.description: If an adversary can escalate privileges, he or she may be able to use those privileges to place malicious code in the system partition, operating system kernel or other boot partition components, where the code may evade detection, may persist after device resets, and may not be removable by the device user. In some cases (e.g., the Samsung Knox warranty bit), the attack may be detected but could result in the device being placed in a state that no longer allows certain functionality.Many Android devices provide the ability to unlock the bootloader for development purposes, but doing so introduces the potential ability for others to maliciously update the kernel or other boot partition code.If the bootloader is not unlocked, it may still be possible to exploit device vulnerabilities to update the code or escalate privileges and then modify the system partition.This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK techniques Modify System Partition and Modify OS Kernel or Boot Partition.

elapsedTime.rationale: Finding an exploit for this could take quite sometime, particularly if the researcher has difficulty reverse engineering the OS

specialistExpertise.rationale: General knowledge of OS kernels, their operation, and how to gain access to them is required for this type of attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attackers need to know several aspects about the boot, os, and kernel layer of the OS in order to perform this type of attack

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: All surfaces of this attack are used upon vehicle startup, but if physical access to the vehicle is required this step becomes more difficult

equipment.rationale: A standard computer and something to physically modify the kernel is required for this attack

threats.name: Modify Isolated Execution Environment
threats.description: If an adversary can escalate privileges, he or she may be able to use those privileges to place malicious code in the ECU's isolated execution environment (TrustZone, SMU, CAAM, SE, TPM, EVITA HSM, SHE, SGX, TEE etc.) where the code can evade detection, may persist after device resets, and may not be removable by the device user. Running code within the isolated execution environment may provide an adversary with the ability to monitor or tamper with overall device behavior. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: A deep understanding of the vehicle architecture, controls, and various cryptography methods used must be understood before this attack can work

specialistExpertise.rationale: The attacker must be able to identify what is within the TEE, how to break into it, and then how to gain access to the information that they are seeking

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of internal systems is required for this attack

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: the TEE surface is available every time the vehicle is used

threats.name: Compromise Cryptographic Security
threats.description: Adversaries may compromise the cryptographic mechanisms used by vehicles to bypass controls that would otherwise protect assets. These assets may be internal to an ECU, or used in communication between ECUs within the vehicle, or with services outside the vehicle. This technique does not cover exploitation of poorly-protected keys. See  ECU Credential Dumping (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0039) & Unsecured Credentials (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0040). Cryptographic methods can be used to protect the security properties of assets both within a vehicle or ECU and between a vehicle and other communication partners. They are intended to be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key. Adversaries can compromise assets within the vehicle (or its ECUs) by exploiting a variety of issues relating to cryptography. Examples and references are given below - these are in no way an exhaustive list. There are a huge number of cryptographic flaws of various kinds which have existed and continue to occur. - The algorithm is inherently weak (Dismantling Megamos Crypto: Wirelessly Lockpicking a Vehicle Immobilizer, Gone in 360 Seconds: Hijacking with Hitag2). Recommendation: use consensus standard cryptography. - The security strength of the cryptography used is not sufficient. Recent recommendations can be found in Recommendation for Key Management: Part 1 - General, Cryptographic Mechanisms: Recommendations and Key Lengths, Version 2024-01. - The implementation of cryptographic primitives is flawed. Recommendation: use carefully selected providers of cryptographic code. Examples of such flaws include: o Information leakage through timing (CWE - CWE-208: Observable Timing Discrepancy (4.16), Challenge 17 Set 3 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges). An example of this has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Parameters which are insufficiently strong in all possible use-cases.  e=3 in RSA encryption of small messages e=3 in RSA signature validation with incorrect padding validation. This has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Summary of RSA flaws: Twenty years of attacks on the RSA Cryptosystem. - The cryptographic primitive does not provide the property the use-case requires. Recommendation: carefully review all uses of cryptography to ensure the correct properties are defended. o For example, encryption does not provide integrity or authenticity. Challenge 16 Set 2 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges. - The structure/protocol has vulnerabilities (despite using a good cryptographic primitive). Recommendation: use well-reviewed (not ad-hoc) structures and protocols: o padding oracles: Practical Padding Oracle Attacks o Reused nonces/IVs: ECDSA-Nonce-Reuse-Exploit-Example o Message extension attacks: Flickr's API Signature Forgery Vulnerability This technique may be used as a precursor to ATM techniques such as: Bypass Code Integrity Protections (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0031) & Bypass UDS Security Access (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0033)

elapsedTime.rationale: A deep understanding of the vehicle architecture, controls, and various cryptography methods used must be understood before this attack can work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of internal systems is required for this attack

threats.name: Privilege Escalation
threats.description: The adversary is trying to gain higher-level permissions. Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on an ECU. Adversaries can often gain initial access to an ECU with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions or capabilities to follow through on their objectives. Common approaches are to take advantage of system weaknesses, misconfigurations, and vulnerabilities. Examples of elevated access include root access and control of adjacent computing environments on the same ECU. These techniques can overlap with Persistence techniques, as OS features that let an adversary persist can execute in an elevated context. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism
threats.description: Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain higher-level permissions. Many modern systems contain native elevation control mechanisms that are intended to limit privileges that a user can perform on an ECU. Authorization has to be granted to specific system users or system processes in order to perform tasks that can be considered of higher risk. An adversary can perform several methods to take advantage of built-in control mechanisms in order to escalate privileges on a system. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

specialistExpertise.rationale: General knowledge of access control systems and the ability to identify the protocols being used by the vehicle is required for this type of attack

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The access control systems of a vehicle are generally static, with only exploits being removed when found via patches. But the core framework generally remains the same

threats.name: Exploit Co-Located Computing Device for Privilege Escalation
threats.description: Adversaries may be able to leverage their access on one of an ECU's computing devices to gain control of another computing device on the same ECU. For example, it may be possible for a compromised USB controller or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth chip to gain control of the operating system running on a separate chip but still part of the same ECU.

elapsedTime.rationale: Given exploits for pre-existing devices may already be known, the attacker will only need to research how to use the device to gain access to their intended effect

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of various types of devices that could be connected to a vehicle and how to exploit them is required for this attack to work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge about specific information exchange protocols within the vehicle may benefit the attacker, but are generally not required for this attack

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Generally these devices will always be connected to the vehicle when they are in operation; leaving a large window of time to be able to exploit them

equipment.rationale: Typically, only a standard computer is required to perform this attack

threats.name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
threats.description: A malicious app can exploit unpatched vulnerabilities in the operating system to obtain escalated privileges. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: A good amount of time is needed for the attacker to research the operating system and find potential exploits that they would benefit from

specialistExpertise.rationale: High-level knowledge of operating systems and potential ways to exploit them are required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: This rating will change depending on the operating system that is used by the vehicle. If it is proprietary the attacker will need sensitive information in order to find exploits, but more public facing operating systems will require less insider information from the attacker

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: This rating depends on how often and well maintained the operating system is, but it is a surface that is always available for attack

threats.name: Exploit Isolated Execution Environment Vulnerability
threats.description: A malicious app or other attack vector could be used to exploit vulnerabilities in code running within a isolated execution environment (IEE), which could include ARM TrustZone, SEs, TPMs, EVITA HSMs, SHEs, SPUs, CAAMs, TEE, or similar. The adversary could then obtain privileges held by the IEE potentially including the ability to access cryptographic keys or other sensitive data. Escalated operating system privileges may be first required in order to have the ability to attack the IEE. If not, privileges within the IEE can potentially be used to exploit the operating system. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: The attacker will need to spend some time researching the TEE of the vehicle to find potential exploits and ways to benefit from them

specialistExpertise.rationale: General knowledge of trusted execution environments and their information flows is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker would need some restricted information in order to achieve this attack, but this information could be found through trial and error/researching

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The TEE is generally static, but depending on where the exploit exists the window of opportunity can shift

equipment.rationale: Specialized equipment will be required for performing this attack

threats.name: Hardware Fault Injection
threats.description: The adversary may attempt fault injection attacks to elevate privileges by 'flipping' bits that control authentication states. For example, through voltage or clock glitching it may be possible to bypass password authentication on debug interfaces. Many different fault injection attacks exist, some require direct physical access to the target ECU and specialized tools (e.g., ChipSHOUTER), while others can be implemented in software (e.g., Row hammer).

elapsedTime.rationale: The attacker will need time to research the components used within the vehicle to find these exploits

specialistExpertise.rationale: Deep knowledge of vehicle components and how to exploit them is required for this attack to function

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Internal knowledge of the vehicles architecture is required for this attack to function

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The components will always be available as a surface

equipment.rationale: specialized equipment is required for this attack to function

threats.name: Process Injection
threats.description: Adversaries may inject code into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Process injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via process injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process. There are many different ways to inject code into a process, many of which abuse legitimate functionalities. These implementations exist for every major OS but are typically platform specific. More sophisticated samples may perform multiple process injections to segment modules and further evade detection, utilizing named pipes or other inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms as a communication channel. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Some time would be required for the attacker to understand the software/firmware of the vehicle, which is subject to change with updates

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of ways to perform arbitrary code execution, and automotive systems is required for this type of attack to work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of the operating system and firmware is required for this type of attack to work

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: While the surface for this attaack is always available, updates would make the window of opportunity smaller

equipment.rationale: While developing the code for the attack only requires a standard computer, delivering the payload to the vehicle will require more specialized equipment

threats.name: Reporgram Co-Located Computing Device for Privilege Escalation
threats.description: The adversary may attempt to elevate privileges by using their access on one of the ECU's computing devices to reprogram another computing device on the same ECU. For example, if an ECU that uses a system-on-chip for most tasks and a separate microcontroller for communication on the vehicle's CAN network, an adversary that can execute code on the SoC could attempt to reprogram the CAN microcontroller.

elapsedTime.rationale: Depending on the device, the co-located computing device will require less research than others to find an exploit that benefits the attacker

specialistExpertise.rationale: The attacker will need to know how to exploit co-located computing devices

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some information regarding the vehicles internal protocols is required for the attacker to benefit from their work, the initial exploits will require less proprietary knowledge

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Depdning on the device, the attack surface for the co-located device will be available quite often

equipment.rationale: Typically, only a standard computer is required for this type of attack to work

threats.name: Compromise Cryptographic Security
threats.description: Adversaries may compromise the cryptographic mechanisms used by vehicles to bypass controls that would otherwise protect assets. These assets may be internal to an ECU, or used in communication between ECUs within the vehicle, or with services outside the vehicle. This technique does not cover exploitation of poorly-protected keys. See  ECU Credential Dumping (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0039) & Unsecured Credentials (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0040). Cryptographic methods can be used to protect the security properties of assets both within a vehicle or ECU and between a vehicle and other communication partners. They are intended to be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key. Adversaries can compromise assets within the vehicle (or its ECUs) by exploiting a variety of issues relating to cryptography. Examples and references are given below - these are in no way an exhaustive list. There are a huge number of cryptographic flaws of various kinds which have existed and continue to occur. - The algorithm is inherently weak (Dismantling Megamos Crypto: Wirelessly Lockpicking a Vehicle Immobilizer, Gone in 360 Seconds: Hijacking with Hitag2). Recommendation: use consensus standard cryptography. - The security strength of the cryptography used is not sufficient. Recent recommendations can be found in Recommendation for Key Management: Part 1 - General, Cryptographic Mechanisms: Recommendations and Key Lengths, Version 2024-01. - The implementation of cryptographic primitives is flawed. Recommendation: use carefully selected providers of cryptographic code. Examples of such flaws include: o Information leakage through timing (CWE - CWE-208: Observable Timing Discrepancy (4.16), Challenge 17 Set 3 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges). An example of this has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Parameters which are insufficiently strong in all possible use-cases.  e=3 in RSA encryption of small messages e=3 in RSA signature validation with incorrect padding validation. This has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Summary of RSA flaws: Twenty years of attacks on the RSA Cryptosystem. - The cryptographic primitive does not provide the property the use-case requires. Recommendation: carefully review all uses of cryptography to ensure the correct properties are defended. o For example, encryption does not provide integrity or authenticity. Challenge 16 Set 2 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges. - The structure/protocol has vulnerabilities (despite using a good cryptographic primitive). Recommendation: use well-reviewed (not ad-hoc) structures and protocols: o padding oracles: Practical Padding Oracle Attacks o Reused nonces/IVs: ECDSA-Nonce-Reuse-Exploit-Example o Message extension attacks: Flickr's API Signature Forgery Vulnerability This technique may be used as a precursor to ATM techniques such as: Bypass Code Integrity Protections (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0031) & Bypass UDS Security Access (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0033)

elapsedTime.rationale: A deep understanding of the vehicle architecture, controls, and various cryptography methods used must be understood before this attack can work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of internal systems is required for this attack

threats.name: Defense Evasion
threats.description: The adversary is attempting to bypass or manipulate security controls. This can include bypassing networking filtering, intrusion detection systems (IDS), and code integrity checks to undermine the protection measures in place. Defense Evasion consists of techniques that adversaries use to advance their objectives despite the presence of defensive measures. This tactic is different from MITRE ATT&CK's 'defense evasion', which is squarely focused on avoiding detection.

threats.name: Bypass Code Integrity Protections
threats.description: Adversaries may seek to circumvent various code integrity protections to install unauthorized firmware or software on the device.
