elapsedTime.rationale: Time researching the signing mechanism s of the vehicle are required for this type of attack

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of arbitrary code execution, and the current signing mechanisms of the vehicle is required for this type of attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of the internal signing mechanisms and their weaknesses are required for this type of attack to work

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Depending on when the signing mechanisms are called, the attack surface may be less available

equipment.rationale: Only a standard computer to generate the code is required for this type of attack to function

threats.name: Bypass Network Filtering
threats.description: Adversaries may disable or modify network filters in order to bypass controls limiting vehicle network usage. Changes could be disabling the entire mechanism as well as adding, deleting, or modifying particular rules. This can be done numerous ways depending on the operating system, including via command-line. Modifying or disabling a system filter may enable adversary C2 communications, lateral movement, and/or data exfiltration that would otherwise not be allowed. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Depending on the type of firewall used, it may take more or less time to find beneficial exploits for the attacker

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of firewall protocols and ways to circumvent them are required for this type of attack to function

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: General information on firewalls is readily available, but the exact implementation may require some insider knowledge that could be discovered through trial and error on the end of the attacker

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Generally, this attack surface is readily available for the attacker

equipment.rationale: Only a standard computer is required for this type of attack

threats.name: Bypass UDS Security Access
threats.description: Adversaries may find ways to bypass or defeat the Universal Diagnostic Services Security Access / mode 0x27 security mechanism. Implementation details for this mechanism are not part of the standard and an adversary could seek to defeat mechanisms that use a common secret value on all devices of a given make and model, static challenge-response mechanisms, mechanisms that use short secrets susceptible to brute forcing, and other approaches including diagnostic session hijacking.

elapsedTime.rationale: information regarding the UDS protocol and potential exploits are readily available information

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of the UDS protocol and how to circumvent it is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Information regarding UDS protocols are readily available

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Access to the UDS surface requires physical access to the vehicle, making the surface more difficult to access to the attacker

equipment.rationale: Only a computer and a device designed to read/write to UDS is required for this attack

threats.name: Bypass Mandatory Access Control
threats.description: Adversaries may find ways to defeat mandatory access control mechanisms such as SELinux or AppArmor. This could include finding a hole' in the policy, or exploiting a vulnerability in the operating system, kernel, or trusted execution environment that allows the adversary to disable mandatory access control.

elapsedTime.rationale: Time spent researching the MAC protocols used by the vehicle are required for the attack to function

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of MAC policies and operating systems is required for this type of attack to function

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge regarding the MAC policies used by the vehicle is required for this attack to be successful

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The MAC protocols and operating systems are generally available to the attacker

equipment.rationale: Some specialized equipment is required to discover MAC vulnerabilities

threats.name: Compromise Cryptographic Security
threats.description: Adversaries may compromise the cryptographic mechanisms used by vehicles to bypass controls that would otherwise protect assets. These assets may be internal to an ECU, or used in communication between ECUs within the vehicle, or with services outside the vehicle. This technique does not cover exploitation of poorly-protected keys. See  ECU Credential Dumping (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0039) & Unsecured Credentials (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0040). Cryptographic methods can be used to protect the security properties of assets both within a vehicle or ECU and between a vehicle and other communication partners. They are intended to be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key. Adversaries can compromise assets within the vehicle (or its ECUs) by exploiting a variety of issues relating to cryptography. Examples and references are given below - these are in no way an exhaustive list. There are a huge number of cryptographic flaws of various kinds which have existed and continue to occur. - The algorithm is inherently weak (Dismantling Megamos Crypto: Wirelessly Lockpicking a Vehicle Immobilizer, Gone in 360 Seconds: Hijacking with Hitag2). Recommendation: use consensus standard cryptography. - The security strength of the cryptography used is not sufficient. Recent recommendations can be found in Recommendation for Key Management: Part 1 - General, Cryptographic Mechanisms: Recommendations and Key Lengths, Version 2024-01. - The implementation of cryptographic primitives is flawed. Recommendation: use carefully selected providers of cryptographic code. Examples of such flaws include: o Information leakage through timing (CWE - CWE-208: Observable Timing Discrepancy (4.16), Challenge 17 Set 3 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges). An example of this has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Parameters which are insufficiently strong in all possible use-cases.  e=3 in RSA encryption of small messages e=3 in RSA signature validation with incorrect padding validation. This has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Summary of RSA flaws: Twenty years of attacks on the RSA Cryptosystem. - The cryptographic primitive does not provide the property the use-case requires. Recommendation: carefully review all uses of cryptography to ensure the correct properties are defended. o For example, encryption does not provide integrity or authenticity. Challenge 16 Set 2 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges. - The structure/protocol has vulnerabilities (despite using a good cryptographic primitive). Recommendation: use well-reviewed (not ad-hoc) structures and protocols: o padding oracles: Practical Padding Oracle Attacks o Reused nonces/IVs: ECDSA-Nonce-Reuse-Exploit-Example o Message extension attacks: Flickr's API Signature Forgery Vulnerability This technique may be used as a precursor to ATM techniques such as: Bypass Code Integrity Protections (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0031) & Bypass UDS Security Access (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0033)

elapsedTime.rationale: A deep understanding of the vehicle architecture, controls, and various cryptography methods used must be understood before this attack can work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of internal systems is required for this attack

threats.name: Credential Access
threats.description: The adversary is trying to steal vehicle network credentials. Credential Access consists of techniques for stealing vehicle network credentials like cryptographic tokens, keys, and passwords. Techniques used to get credentials include credential dumping and collecting unsecured credentials stored on ECU file systems. Using legitimate credentials can give adversaries access to vehicle systems and make them harder to detect. Adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: Exploit Isolated Execution Environment Vulnerability
threats.description: A malicious app or other attack vector could be used to exploit vulnerabilities in code running within a isolated execution environment (IEE), which could include ARM TrustZone, SEs, TPMs, EVITA HSMs, SHEs, SPUs, CAAMs, TEE, or similar. The adversary could then obtain privileges held by the IEE potentially including the ability to access cryptographic keys or other sensitive data. Escalated operating system privileges may be first required in order to have the ability to attack the IEE. If not, privileges within the IEE can potentially be used to exploit the operating system. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: The attacker will need to spend some time researching the TEE of the vehicle to find potential exploits and ways to benefit from them

specialistExpertise.rationale: General knowledge of trusted execution environments and their information flows is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: The attacker would need some restricted information in order to achieve this attack, but this information could be found through trial and error/researching

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The TEE is generally static, but depending on where the exploit exists the window of opportunity can shift

equipment.rationale: Specialized equipment will be required for performing this attack

threats.name: Capture SMS Message
threats.description: A malicious application could capture sensitive data sent via SMS, including authentication credentials. SMS is frequently used to transmit codes used for multi-factor authentication. On Android, a malicious application must request and obtain permission (either at app install time or run time) in order to receive SMS messages. Alternatively, a malicious application could attempt to perform an operating system privilege escalation attack to bypass the permission requirement. This technique description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: SMS protocol information is readily available, but time researching the specific implementation within the vehicle is required for the attack to be successful

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of SMS exploits and ways to intercept the messages are required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge about the defenses surrounding the SMS implementation within the vehicle is required for the attack to work

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The surface is only available when the service is being used

equipment.rationale: Only a standard computer is required for this attack

threats.name: Input Capture
threats.description: Adversaries may capture user input to obtain credentials or other information from the user through various methods. Malware may masquerade as a legitimate third-party keyboard to record user keystrokes. On Android, users must explicitly authorize the use of third-party keyboard apps. Users should be advised to use extreme caution before granting this authorization when it is requested. On Android, malware may abuse accessibility features to record keystrokes by registering an AccessibilityService class, overriding the onAccessibilityEvent method, and listening for the AccessibilityEvent.TYPE_VIEW_TEXT_CHANGED event type. The event object passed into the function will contain the data that the user typed. Additional methods of keylogging may be possible if root access is available. This technique was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge on general man-in-the-middle attacks are required for this type of attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge about the input storage is required for this attack

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: While physicals access to the vehicle may not be required, it does require that the user be present and actively using the vehicle

threats.name: Input Prompt
threats.description: The operating system and installed applications often have legitimate needs to prompt the user for sensitive information such as account credentials, bank account information, or Personally Identifiable Information (PII). Adversaries may mimic this functionality to prompt users for sensitive information. Compared to traditional PCs, the constrained display size of vehicle screens may impair the ability to provide users with contextual information, making users more susceptible to this technique's use. Specific approaches to this technique include: - Impersonate the identity of a legitimate application: A malicious application could impersonate the identity of a legitimate application (e.g. use the same application name and/or icon) and get installed on the vehicle. The malicious app could then prompt the user for sensitive information. - Display a prompt on top of a running legitimate application: A malicious application could display a prompt on top of a running legitimate application to trick users into entering sensitive information into the malicious application rather than the legitimate application. Typically, the malicious application would need to know when the targeted application (and individual activity within the targeted application) is running in the foreground, so that the malicious application knows when to display its prompt. Android 5.0 and 5.1.1, respectively, increased the difficulty of determining the current foreground application through modifications to the ActivityManager API. A malicious application can still abuse Android's accessibility features to determine which application is currently in the foreground. Approaches to display a prompt include: 1) A malicious application could start a new activity on top of a running legitimate application. Android 10 places new restrictions on the ability for an application to start a new activity on top of another application, which may make it more difficult for adversaries to utilize this technique. 2) A malicious application could create an application overlay window on top of a running legitimate application. Applications must hold the SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW permission to create overlay windows. This permission is handled differently than typical Android permissions, and at least under certain conditions is automatically granted to applications installed from the Google Play Store. The SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW permission and its associated ability to create application overlay windows are expected to be deprecated in a future release of Android in favor of a new API. - Fake device notifications: A malicious application could send fake device notifications to the user. Clicking on the device notification could trigger the malicious application to display an input prompt. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Time must be spent researching how to provide a seemingly legitimate prompt to the end-user

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge on social engineering and how to present the prompt to the end-user is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge about the vehicles workflow and stylings are required in order for the attack to appear legitimate and function

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The user must be present within the vehicle

equipment.rationale: A computer is required, and depending on the intended prompt, some specialized equipment may be needed

threats.name: Network Sniffing
threats.description: Adversaries may sniff vehicle network traffic to capture information about an environment, including authentication material passed over the vehicle network. Network sniffing refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent over a wired or wireless vehicle network connection. An adversary may place a network interface into promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to capture a larger amount of data. Data captured via this technique may include user credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol. Techniques for name service resolution poisoning can also be used to capture credentials to websites, proxies, and internal systems by redirecting traffic to an adversary. Network sniffing may also reveal configuration details, such as running services, version numbers, and other network characteristics (e.g. IP addresses, hostnames, VLAN IDs) necessary for subsequent Lateral Movement and/or Defense Evasion activities.Adversaries may also try to collect vehicle telemetry, including propulsion system status (e.g., hard acceleration or braking), whether vehicle enclosures are locked / unlocked, etc. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge about the vehicles communication protocols and how to intercept it is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge about the internal communication system is required for this attack to function

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Typically these communication protocols are available to the attacker

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required for this attack to work

threats.name: ECU Credential Dumping
threats.description: Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login and credential material, normally in the form of a hash or a clear text password, from the operating system and software. Credentials can then be used to perform Lateral Movement and access restricted information. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Depending on the operating system, time spent researching the specific vulnerabilities that may be present is required before this attack can be attempted

specialistExpertise.rationale: General knowledge about operating systems, their storage methodologies, and penetration testing is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Proprietary operating systems require a great amount of internal knowledge in order to find and utilize exploits

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Accessing the operating system may be difficult to perform remotely

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required for this attack

threats.name: Unsecured Credentials
threats.description: Adversaries may search compromised systems to find and obtain insecurely stored credentials. These credentials can be stored and/or misplaced in many locations on a system, including plaintext files (e.g. bash history), operating system or application-specific repositories (e.g. credentials in registry), or other specialized files/artifacts (e.g. Private Keys). This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Some time may be needed to discover that the credentials are unsecured; but once that has been discovered it takes very little time to access them

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of operating systems and computational storage is required for this attack to work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge that the credentials are unsecured is required, but this can be found through trial and error on the attackers end and will be quickly discovered if attempted

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: unsecured credentials are always considered to be available, but if physical access to the vehicle is required it my shorten the window of opportunity

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required

threats.name: URI Hijacking
threats.description: Adversaries may register Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) to intercept sensitive data. Applications regularly register URIs with the operating system to act as a response handler for various actions, such as logging into an app using an external account via single sign-on. This allows redirections to that specific URI to be intercepted by the application. If a malicious application were to register for a URI that was already in use by a genuine application, the malicious application may be able to intercept data intended for the genuine application or perform a phishing attack against the genuine application. Intercepted data may include OAuth authorization codes or tokens that could be used by the malicious application to gain access to resources. This technique description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Researching and discovering exploits within the vehicles URI implementation will require a moderate amount of time

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of the URI and how to redirect it is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of the specific URI implementation and potential controls put into place are required for the attack to be successful

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: The URI is generally an available surface to the attacker

equipment.rationale: A standard computer is required for this attack

threats.name: Discovery
threats.description: The adversary is trying to figure out the vehicle environment. Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about a vehicle's systems and its internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what's around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective. This tactic does not include techniques or other work that is performed during an offline / reverse engineering phase of an attack  this is currently out of scope of the auto threat matrix. In other words, the techniques are listed here if they are part of an active attack, but they are not listed if they only need to be used during a reverse engineering / exploit development phase. This tactic was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: File and Directory Discovery
threats.description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of an ECU for certain information within a file system. Adversaries may use the information from this technique during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. Many command shell utilities can be used to obtain this information. Examples include dir, tree, ls, find, and locate. Custom tools may also be used to gather file and directory information and interact with the Native API. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Highly variable depending on the methodology used, but knowledge of the vehicles directory system is required and must be researched by the attacker first

specialistExpertise.rationale: Depending on the strategy used, this rating is subject to change. A brute force attack is quite simple to perform, but the use of a web crawler requires more expertise

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: An understanding of the directory system used by the vehicle and potential controls is required by the attacker

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Directory systems within vehicles typically do not change, with the only variable being the security surrounding those directories

equipment.rationale: Depending on the attack, either a standard computer or more specialized equipment will be required

threats.name: Location Tracking
threats.description: An adversary could use a malicious or exploited application to surreptitiously track the vehicle's physical location through use of standard operating system APIs. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Researching a methodology that allows for undetected tracking will require some time

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of both vehicle architecture and software vulnerabilities are required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of the specific internals of the vehicle is required

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: While the physical architecture is static, updates to the software will shift the window of opprotunity

equipment.rationale: While it is potentially possible to perform this using native navigation tools on the vehicle (GPS), it is possible that specialized equipment could be used to perform this action

threats.name: Network Service Scanning
threats.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on a vehicle's ECUs, including those that may be vulnerable to remote software exploitation. Methods to acquire this information include port scans and vulnerability scans using tools that are brought onto a system. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Scanning and probing a network is quite simple to do and takes very little time to perform

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of probing/scanning and pen testing is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of the internal protocols of the vehicle are required for this attack to function. IE understanding how to bypass the firewall

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Scans/probes can be performed during the lifecycle of the car. Physical scans will require access to the vehicle

equipment.rationale: While it is possible to perform this attack with a standard computer, using ports to scan will require specialized equipment

threats.name: Process Discovery
threats.description: Adversaries may attempt to get information about running processes on a system. Information obtained could be used to gain an understanding of common software/applications running on systems within the vehicle network. Adversaries may use the information from process discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Research time to find ways to read the processes and find a beneficial exploit requires some time

specialistExpertise.rationale: Automotive and general computational knowledge is required to perform this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Additional knowledge about the vehicles control systems and cryptography is required for this attack

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: This can occur at any point during runtime

threats.name: Software Discovery
threats.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of software and software versions that are installed on a vehicle. Adversaries may use the information from this technique during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. Adversaries may attempt to enumerate software for a variety of reasons, such as figuring out what security measures are present or if the compromised system has a version of software that is vulnerable to exploitation for privilege escalation. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Time is required to find the vulnerabilities with this type of attack

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of both automotive and computational systems are required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge about internal controls and how to bypass them is required to find the information that the attacker is looking for

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: This attack can typically be performed at anytime

equipment.rationale: Some information can be found with a computer, but other parts of the system require specialized equipment to find vulnerabilities

threats.name: System Information Discovery
threats.description: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the ECU's operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture. Adversaries may use the information from this technique during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Time is required to discover useful information in this type of attack

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of both automotive and computational systems are required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of internal controls and how to bypass them is required for the attacker to get actionable information

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Window of opportunity is only limited by frequency of updates and their security

equipment.rationale: While some information can be found with  computer, other aspects will require more specialized equipment

threats.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
threats.description: Adversaries may look for details about the network configuration and settings of systems they access or through information discovery of remote systems. Several operating system administration utilities exist that can be used to gather this information. Examples include Arp, ipconfig/ifconfig, nbtstat, and route. Adversaries may use the information from System Network Configuration Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.

elapsedTime.rationale: Some time is required to discover vulnerabilities within a network configuration

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of network protocols is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Knowledge of internal controls is required, but is something that an attacker could overcome with time

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Window of opportunity is only limited by updates and their security

equipment.rationale: Only a computer is required for this attack

threats.name: System Network Connections Discovery
threats.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network. An adversary who gains access to a system that is part of a cloud-based environment may map out Virtual Private Clouds or Virtual Networks in order to determine what systems and services are connected. The actions performed are likely the same types of discovery techniques depending on the operating system, but the resulting information may include details about the networked cloud environment relevant to the adversary's goals. Cloud providers may have different ways in which their virtual networks operate. Utilities and commands that acquire this information include netstat, 'net use,' and 'net session' with Net. In Linux, netstat and lsof can be used to list current connections. who -a and w can be used to show which users are currently logged in, similar to 'net session'. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Some time is required to find vulnerabilities

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge about networking protocols is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of the internal controls is required, but an attacker can discover and overcome these

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Window of opportunity is only limited by frequency of updates

equipment.rationale: Only a computer is required to perform this type of attack

threats.name: Lateral Movement
threats.description: The adversary is trying to move through the vehicle network. Lateral movement consists of techniques that enable an adversary to access and control remote systems on a vehicle network and could, but does not necessarily, include execution of tools on ECUs. The lateral movement techniques could allow an adversary to gather information from a system without needing additional tools, such as a remote access tool. This definition was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

threats.name: Abuse Standard Diagnostic Protocol for Lateral Movement
threats.description: The adversary could try to abuse standard diagnostic protocols (e.g., unified diagnostic services) to move laterally inside the vehicle network. For example, an adversary that can send diagnostic commands could attempt to use UDS 'download and execute' or 'write memory by address' capabilities to gain code execution on an ECU on the vehicle network.

elapsedTime.rationale: time is required to discover the vulnerabilities required for this attack

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge of UDS, general automotive systems, and computational systems is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: In-depth knowledge of the vehicle components, their vulnerabilities, and software is required

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: only limited by the length of time between updates to software

equipment.rationale: Some specialized equipment may be required for this attack

threats.name: Bridge Vehicle Networks
threats.description: The adversary may seek to bridge vehicle vehicle networks to obtain their objectives. Some ECUs may possess multiple interfaces to the vehicle network, including interfaces that use different networking technologies, and an adversary could modify these ECUs to bridge networks that would otherwise be separated. For example, an adversary that has gained initial access on an ECU with a connection to a vehicle's Ethernet network may attempt to modify an ECU that is connected to the vehicle's Ethernet and CAN networks so that they can extend their reach to ECU on the vehicle's CAN network.

elapsedTime.rationale: A great deal of time is required for this type of attack assuming appropriate controls are in place

specialistExpertise.rationale: Automotive, computational, and network knowledge is required for this attack

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Highly in-depth information regarding the vehicle must be known

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: dependent on consistent vehicle versions, components, and software

equipment.rationale: Specialized equipment is required

threats.name: Exploit ECU for Lateral Movement
threats.description: Adversaries may exploit an ECU's services to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a vehicle network. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. A common goal for post-compromise exploitation of remote services is for lateral movement to enable control of additional ECUs on the vehicle network. An adversary may need to determine if the remote system is in a vulnerable state, which may be done through network service scanning or other discovery methods looking for common, vulnerable software that may be deployed in the network, the lack of certain patches that may indicate vulnerabilities, or security software that may be used to detect or contain remote exploitation. Depending on the permissions level of the vulnerable remote service an adversary may achieve exploitation for privilege escalation as a result of lateral movement exploitation as well. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: An ecu with proper controls will take time for the attacker to find vulnerabilities

specialistExpertise.rationale: Attacker must be knowledgeable about automotive and computational systems

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge about the internal systems of the vehicle must be known

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Window of opportunity depends on the frequency of updates to the firmware and software

equipment.rationale: Some specialized equipment may be required to exploit the ECU

threats.name: Remote Services
threats.description: Adversaries may attempt to log into a service specifically designed to accept remote connections, such as telnet, SSH, and VNC. The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user. This technique's description was adapted from MITRE ATT&CK.

elapsedTime.rationale: Some time is required to discover a way to be seen as an authentic service connected to the vehicle

specialistExpertise.rationale: Knowledge about networking and computational systems is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of the internal systems and controls is required

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: window of opportunity varies depending on frequency of updates

equipment.rationale: Some versions of this attack may require specialized equipment to function

threats.name: Reprogram ECU for Lateral Movement
threats.description: The adversary may attempt to move laterally in a vehicle's network by reprogramming an ECU via its software update mechanisms. This can be successful if an ECU on the vehicle network does not possess a mechanism to verify the authenticity of a software update. Flaws in the verification mechanism, including weak cryptography, coding errors, and the failure to address version rollback attacks, can result in Bypass code signing.

elapsedTime.rationale: A great deal of time is required to find a way to successfully complete this attack

specialistExpertise.rationale: Highly in-depth knowledge about automotive and computational systems is required

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: In-depth knowledge about the automotive and computational systems of the vehicle is required.

windowOfOpportunity.rationale: Window of opportunity varies depending on frequency and quality of updates

equipment.rationale: While it may be possible to complete this type of attack with just a computer, some specialized equipment may be required

threats.name: Compromise Cryptographic Security
threats.description: Adversaries may compromise the cryptographic mechanisms used by vehicles to bypass controls that would otherwise protect assets. These assets may be internal to an ECU, or used in communication between ECUs within the vehicle, or with services outside the vehicle. This technique does not cover exploitation of poorly-protected keys. See  ECU Credential Dumping (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0039) & Unsecured Credentials (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0007/ATM-T0040). Cryptographic methods can be used to protect the security properties of assets both within a vehicle or ECU and between a vehicle and other communication partners. They are intended to be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key. Adversaries can compromise assets within the vehicle (or its ECUs) by exploiting a variety of issues relating to cryptography. Examples and references are given below - these are in no way an exhaustive list. There are a huge number of cryptographic flaws of various kinds which have existed and continue to occur. - The algorithm is inherently weak (Dismantling Megamos Crypto: Wirelessly Lockpicking a Vehicle Immobilizer, Gone in 360 Seconds: Hijacking with Hitag2). Recommendation: use consensus standard cryptography. - The security strength of the cryptography used is not sufficient. Recent recommendations can be found in Recommendation for Key Management: Part 1 - General, Cryptographic Mechanisms: Recommendations and Key Lengths, Version 2024-01. - The implementation of cryptographic primitives is flawed. Recommendation: use carefully selected providers of cryptographic code. Examples of such flaws include: o Information leakage through timing (CWE - CWE-208: Observable Timing Discrepancy (4.16), Challenge 17 Set 3 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges). An example of this has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Parameters which are insufficiently strong in all possible use-cases.  e=3 in RSA encryption of small messages e=3 in RSA signature validation with incorrect padding validation. This has been observed in a fielded automotive product. o Summary of RSA flaws: Twenty years of attacks on the RSA Cryptosystem. - The cryptographic primitive does not provide the property the use-case requires. Recommendation: carefully review all uses of cryptography to ensure the correct properties are defended. o For example, encryption does not provide integrity or authenticity. Challenge 16 Set 2 - The Cryptopals Crypto Challenges. - The structure/protocol has vulnerabilities (despite using a good cryptographic primitive). Recommendation: use well-reviewed (not ad-hoc) structures and protocols: o padding oracles: Practical Padding Oracle Attacks o Reused nonces/IVs: ECDSA-Nonce-Reuse-Exploit-Example o Message extension attacks: Flickr's API Signature Forgery Vulnerability This technique may be used as a precursor to ATM techniques such as: Bypass Code Integrity Protections (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0031) & Bypass UDS Security Access (https://atm.automotiveisac.com/technique/ATM-TA0006/ATM-T0033)

elapsedTime.rationale: A deep understanding of the vehicle architecture, controls, and various cryptography methods used must be understood before this attack can work

knowledgeOfTheItemOrComponent.rationale: Some knowledge of internal systems is required for this attack
